incomeBrackets.label: Working Poor
incomeBrackets.description: It's a grind. Every dollar is stretched. Focus on essentials for the family.

incomeBrackets.label: Low Income
incomeBrackets.description: Budgeting is an art form. A family night out for pizza is a rare, celebrated event.

incomeBrackets.label: Lower Middle Class
incomeBrackets.description: Essentials are covered, maybe some family activities. Saving is tough but not impossible.

incomeBrackets.label: Middle Class
incomeBrackets.description: Comfortable family life, but mindful of spending. Building a nest egg and a 401k.

incomeBrackets.label: Upper Middle Class
incomeBrackets.description: Family life's pretty good! More treats, less stress. Investments are growing.

incomeBrackets.label: Affluent
incomeBrackets.description: Enjoying finer things with the family. Weekend getaways and nice dinners are regular.

incomeBrackets.label: High Income
incomeBrackets.description: Luxury choices become more accessible for the family. Quality of life upgrades.

incomeBrackets.label: Wealthy
incomeBrackets.description: Premium experiences are standard. Financial advisor helps manage family wealth.

incomeBrackets.label: Very Wealthy
incomeBrackets.description: Elite living for the family. Significant choices in education and travel.

incomeBrackets.label: Ultra High Net Worth
incomeBrackets.description: Exclusive access and bespoke services. Family hobbies can be extravagant.

incomeBrackets.label: Millionaire
incomeBrackets.description: Congrats, you made it! Smart allocation and enjoying the fruits with your family.

incomeBrackets.label: Multi-Millionaire
incomeBrackets.description: Significant financial freedom. Global travel and investment opportunities for the family.

incomeBrackets.label: Ultra Wealthy
incomeBrackets.description: The world is your family's playground. Legacy planning and philanthropy.

incomeBrackets.label: Ultra Elite
incomeBrackets.description: Your family's biggest worry? Which continent for the summer. Influencing broader causes.

incomeBrackets.label: Billionaire Class
incomeBrackets.description: Price tags are suggestions. Next stop: shaping global change or funding major family endeavors.

items.title: Home Cooking on a Budget
items.desc: Staples like pasta, rice, beans. Focus on supermarket private labels. A rare treat: $5 pizza or local takeaway.
items.financialNote: Food budget is extremely tight, maximizing nutrition per dollar.

items.title: Occasional Casual Family Meals
items.desc: Local diners or casual chains like Applebee's or Chili's once or twice a month. Aware of family meal deals.
items.financialNote: Dining out is a budgeted treat. Still primarily home-cooking.

items.title: Regular Foodie Exploration
items.desc: Weekly family dinners at popular local restaurants, food halls, or trying diverse cuisines.
items.financialNote: Dining out is a regular part of the lifestyle.

items.title: Premium Pantry & Organic Focus
items.desc: Regular shopping at Whole Foods, Trader Joe's, or local organic markets. Investing in better quality ingredients.
items.financialNote: Prioritizing quality and specialty ingredients.

items.title: Fine Dining Experiences
items.desc: Monthly reservations at acclaimed local restaurants, possibly with tasting menus. Exploring restaurants noted in Michelin Guide.
items.financialNote: High-quality dining is a significant leisure expense.

items.title: Private Chef & Exclusive Reservations
items.desc: Personal chef for special family occasions or regular meal prep. Securing tables at globally renowned, hard-to-book establishments.
items.financialNote: Ultimate convenience and exclusivity in dining.

items.title: Renting in Less Central Areas / Shared Living
items.desc: Renting a smaller apartment or sharing a house, often further from city centers. Furniture is often second-hand.
items.financialNote: Rent/housing is the largest expense, often >40-50% of income.

items.title: Modest Apartment or Starter Condo
items.desc: Renting a 1-2BR apartment in a decent neighborhood or a small condo. Basic but functional amenities and furniture from IKEA/Wayfair.
items.financialNote: Housing is a primary, manageable expense, typically 30-40% of income.

items.title: Small Starter Home or Larger Rental
items.desc: Owning a small starter home in an area with good public schools, or renting a 2-3BR apartment/townhouse. Focus on space and safety.
items.financialNote: Prioritizing a safe environment for kids, often at the edge of affordability.

items.title: Comfortable Home Ownership / Quality Rental
items.desc: Owning a modest single-family home in a desirable neighborhood or renting a modern apartment with amenities. Upgrading to better quality furniture (West Elm, Pottery Barn).
items.financialNote: Managing mortgage or higher rental costs. Typically 25-35% of income.

items.title: Luxury Home or Upscale Apartment
items.desc: Spacious, well-appointed home in a prime neighborhood, or a luxury condo with premium amenities. May involve an interior designer for renovations.
items.financialNote: Property is a significant asset and reflection of status.

items.title: Multiple Luxury Properties & Household Staff
items.desc: Primary residence in an exclusive enclave, plus vacation homes. Employing full-time staff: house manager, private chef, nannies, etc.
items.financialNote: Managing a portfolio of international properties with significant upkeep and staffing.

items.title: Public Transit & Walking
items.desc: Reliant on local bus, subway, or walking. If a car is owned, it's older and high-mileage, with repairs being a major budget concern.
items.financialNote: Transportation costs minimized. Car ownership is a significant, unpredictable expense.

items.title: Dependable Used Car
items.desc: Owning a reliable used car (e.g., 5-8 year old Toyota Corolla, Honda CR-V). Focus on fuel efficiency and lower maintenance costs.
items.financialNote: Car is a tool for commuting and family needs.

items.title: Newer Practical Car or Entry EV
items.desc: A new or certified pre-owned practical family car (e.g., Toyota RAV4, Kia Telluride). Possibly an entry-level EV. Focus on safety and modern features.
items.financialNote: Managing a car loan and comprehensive insurance.

items.title: Luxury Daily Driver
items.desc: Driving a new or recent model luxury SUV or sedan (e.g., Tesla Model Y/S, BMW X5, Porsche Macan). A two-car household is common.
items.financialNote: Comfort, performance, and brand prestige are important.

items.title: Exotic Cars & Private Driver
items.desc: Owning high-performance sports cars (Ferrari, Lamborghini) or employing a full-time chauffeur for daily transport.
items.financialNote: Cars as passion assets or for ultimate convenience.

items.title: Staycations & Local Outings
items.desc: Exploring local parks, free museums, community events. Annual family camping trip at a local campsite.
items.financialNote: Travel budget is minimal to non-existent.

items.title: Budget Domestic Trips
items.desc: Annual family vacation via driving or budget airlines. Staying in budget hotels or basic Airbnb rentals.
items.financialNote: Travel is carefully planned and saved for.

items.title: Introductory International Travel / Theme Parks
items.desc: First family trips to an all-inclusive resort in Mexico/Caribbean, a week in a major European city, or a trip to Disney/Universal.
items.financialNote: Travel is a regular, planned expense for creating family memories.

items.title: Business Class Travel & Luxury Resorts
items.desc: Flying business class for long-haul flights. Staying at 5-star resorts (e.g., Four Seasons, St. Regis). Tailored family adventures like African safaris.
items.financialNote: Travel is a significant leisure investment, focused on premium experiences.

items.title: First Class Suites & Private Aviation
items.desc: Flying first-class suites or chartering private jets for family travel. Extended, multi-continent trips. Chartering superyachts.
items.financialNote: Ultimate luxury, privacy, and convenience in travel.

items.title: Free & Low-Cost Fun
items.desc: Utilizing public libraries, free local concerts, hiking. Streaming via ad-supported tiers or shared family accounts.
items.financialNote: Entertainment relies on free or very low-cost community resources.

items.title: Local Events & Streaming Subscriptions
items.desc: Catching a movie at matinee prices, attending local fairs. Subscribing to 1-2 basic streaming services.
items.financialNote: Small, planned entertainment expenses.

items.title: Major Concerts & Live Sports
items.desc: Attending concerts or professional sporting events a few times a year. Enhanced home entertainment with a good 4K TV and current gaming console.
items.financialNote: Budgeting for higher-cost entertainment experiences.

items.title: VIP Experiences & Season Tickets
items.desc: VIP packages for concerts/festivals. Season tickets (club level) for favorite sports teams. High-end hobbies like collecting art or fine wines.
items.financialNote: Premium access and hobbies become significant investments.

items.title: Courtside, Backstage & Gala Access
items.desc: Courtside seats at major sporting events, front row at Fashion Week. Attending exclusive galas and charity balls. Patronage of the arts.
items.financialNote: Access to the most exclusive entertainment and cultural events.

items.title: Public School & Library Resources
items.desc: Children attend local public schools. Heavy reliance on public library and free online resources like Khan Academy.
items.financialNote: Education primarily via free public resources.

items.title: Public University (In-State) / Trade School
items.desc: Children may attend in-state public universities with aid/loans, or pursue vocational training. Adults might take online certificate courses.
items.financialNote: Managing student loan debt is a significant concern.

items.title: Choice of Public or Private University
items.desc: Children attend well-regarded state universities or private universities with aid. Regular contributions to 529 plans.
items.financialNote: Strategic planning for education costs.

items.title: Elite Universities & Private Tutoring
items.desc: Children attend highly selective universities (Ivy League, Oxbridge). Hiring private tutors for test prep. Adults may pursue executive MBAs.
items.financialNote: Education costs are a significant but manageable investment.

items.title: Elite Global Education & University Endowments
items.desc: Children attend prestigious international boarding schools. Custom educational programs. Significant philanthropic contributions to universities.
items.financialNote: Providing the most exclusive global education and shaping institutions.

items.title: Public Health Services & ER
items.desc: Reliant on community clinics, public health services, or emergency rooms for urgent care. Health is often reactive, not proactive, due to cost concerns.
items.financialNote: Medical debt is a significant risk.

items.title: Basic Health Insurance
items.desc: Typically have an employer-sponsored or marketplace plan. Managing deductibles and co-pays is a key part of the budget.

items.title: Focus on Children's Health
items.desc: Prioritizing children's check-ups, dental, and vision care, sometimes at the expense of parents' own non-urgent care.

items.title: Good Insurance & Preventative Care
items.desc: Able to afford better health, dental, and vision insurance plans. Focus shifts to regular check-ups and screenings for the whole family.

items.title: Gym Memberships & Fitness Classes
items.desc: Joining a standard gym (e.g., LA Fitness) or participating in local fitness classes. Maybe a Peloton subscription.

items.title: Boutique Fitness & Personal Training
items.desc: Memberships to high-end gyms or specialized studios (e.g., Equinox, Orangetheory). May hire a personal trainer.

items.title: Mental Health & Proactive Wellness
items.desc: Regular therapy, coaching, or subscriptions to wellness apps (Headspace, Calm) are common. Massages and other treatments are regular.

items.title: Concierge Medicine & Wellness Retreats
items.desc: Paying a retainer for 24/7 direct access to a primary care doctor (concierge medicine). Attending multi-day health and wellness retreats.

items.title: Advanced Health Optimization
items.desc: Access to advanced diagnostic screenings, genetic testing, and nutritionists to optimize health and longevity.

items.title: DIY Everything & Community Support
items.desc: Haircuts at home, all cleaning, cooking, and repairs done by family. Relying on friends and family for childcare.
items.financialNote: Time is traded for cost savings.

items.title: Basic Maintenance & Occasional Convenience
items.desc: Budget haircuts. Occasional use of a handyman or meal kit delivery with a discount offer.
items.financialNote: Convenience services are infrequent splurges.

items.title: Regular Personal Care & Home Help
items.desc: Monthly salon visits, bi-weekly house cleaning service, regular lawn care. Frequent food delivery. Gym memberships.
items.financialNote: Services to save time and maintain quality of life.

items.title: Concierge & Comprehensive Household Support
items.desc: Part-time personal assistant, personal shopper, premium spa treatments. Full-time or regular part-time nanny.
items.financialNote: High-touch services for personalized convenience.

items.title: Full Estate Management & Elite Concierge
items.desc: Employing a full household team (butler, chef, security). Membership with global concierge services (e.g., Quintessentially) for any request.
items.financialNote: Running a large household like a small business. Access to a global fulfillment network.

items.title: Basic Banking & Survival Mode
items.desc: Focus on immediate needs. May use check-cashing services. Debt is often high-interest. No investments.
items.financialNote: Financial stability is precarious.

items.title: Building Emergency Fund & Basic Retirement
items.desc: Goal: 3-6 months of expenses in a high-yield savings account. Starting 401k/IRA contributions with target-date funds.
items.financialNote: Laying the groundwork for financial security.

items.title: Maxing Retirement Accounts & Diversification
items.desc: Aiming to max out 401k/IRA/HSA. Building a diversified portfolio with low-cost index funds. May use robo-advisors.
items.financialNote: Systematic wealth accumulation phase.

items.title: Comprehensive Financial Planning
items.desc: Engage a Certified Financial Planner (CFP). Focus on tax optimization, robust insurance, and foundational estate planning.
items.financialNote: Professional guidance for growing wealth and complexity.

items.title: Advanced Wealth Management / Private Banking
items.desc: Working with private bankers at firms like Morgan Stanley or Merrill Lynch. Access to alternative investments (hedge funds, private equity).
items.financialNote: High-touch management for significant wealth.

items.title: Dedicated Family Office / Institutional Management
items.desc: Establishing a single-family office for direct investments in venture capital, real estate, etc. Focus on multi-generational wealth preservation.
items.financialNote: Holistic management of substantial, global family wealth as an enterprise.
